video:video.video:title: Do eggs contain the secrets of the universe?
video:video.video:description: Eggs are amazing. They're the pinnacle of design and possibly the shape of the universe itself. Welcome to the wonderful world of eggs.

video:video.video:title: Do we need a new understanding of national identity?
video:video.video:description: Political scientist and author Francis Fukuyama says we need national identities that unite rather than divide us.

video:video.video:title: How to win a (Rugby) World Cup
video:video.video:description: Find your mantra. Look forward. Former England rugby star Maggie Alphonsi shares her tips for success.

video:video.video:title: The secret language of feet
video:video.video:description: What do your feet reveal about you? More than you might think... A whizz through some foot facts.

video:video.video:title: UK's first sign language poetry slam
video:video.video:description: Deaf poets fight it out in the UK's first ever poetry slam for users of sign language.

video:video.video:title: Libertarianism: What is it? A simple guide
video:video.video:description: What is libertarianism? And why do its proponents want the state kept at arm's length? Philosopher Julian Baggini explores this key -ism.

video:video.video:title: What a bruised boxer tells us about ancient art
video:video.video:description: Mary Beard argues that a 2,000 year-old sculpture of a brutalised boxer represents an attack on the body culture of the ancient Greeks.

video:video.video:title: Hungry? A brief history of the humble sandwich
video:video.video:description: From the Earl of Sandwich, to 'mouth distorters', to the ubiquitous quick lunch, food historian Annie Gray tells the story of the sandwich.

video:video.video:title: What's the point of women's rights?
video:video.video:description: Human rights lawyer Cherie Blair argues the economic case for ending gender inequality is strong, but the moral case is even stronger.

video:video.video:title: How to speak when you don't have a voice

video:video.video:title: Why baldness is so hard to cure
video:video.video:description: Every year people spend billions trying to get their lost hair back. So why haven't we found a cure? With science writer Stephen Buranyi.

video:video.video:title: The funny thing about... being little
video:video.video:description: Comedian Tanyalee Davis has a form of dwarfism called diastrophic dysplasia. She talks about some of the challenges and misconceptions.

video:video.video:title: What can Oscar Wilde tell us about Kim Kardashian?
video:video.video:description: Have we always had celebrities? And how are our ideas of celebrity changing? A brief cultural history of celebrity.

video:video.video:title: 'We need to stop the schizophrenia stigma'
video:video.video:description: Esme Weijun Wang has schizoaffective disorder and says to break the taboo around this mental illness more people need to tell their stories.

video:video.video:title: What happens when fans take it too far?
video:video.video:description: What happens when fans turn against their idols? Steve Rainey of Radio Ulster explores what happens when things get obsessive.

video:video.video:title: The first fight scene in European art
video:video.video:description: Simon Schama introduces us to Pylos Combat Agate - one of the finest works of prehistoric Greek art ever discovered.

video:video.video:title: How can we use social media more safely?
video:video.video:description: Five tips on how we can use social media more safely.

video:video.video:title: The women changing the face of motor racing
video:video.video:description: Racing driving is a very male-dominated sport, but a growing number of women - like Alice Powell - are changing that.

video:video.video:title: Plato's take on democracy and referendums
video:video.video:description: What is the best form of governance? And where do referendums fit in? Philosopher Lindsey Porter explores Plato's take on it all.

video:video.video:title: How to create the perfect atmosphere in a stadium
video:video.video:description: How clever design can help fans make a bigger impact on the action.

video:video.video:title: How stories shape our minds
video:video.video:description: Stories are just stories, right? Not really. They are also incredibly powerful - and can both reduce prejudice, and help persuade.

video:video.video:title: The curious origin of the high heel
video:video.video:description: High-heeled shoes weren’t always worn by women – the very first heels were actually designed as military footwear.

video:video.video:title: What really happened to this £10m racehorse?
video:video.video:description: One of the world's most valuable racehorses disappeared in 1983. Thirty-five years on, Alison Millar finds out what really happened.

video:video.video:title: Why do we stand on two legs?
video:video.video:description: Very few creatures in the animal kingdom stand on two legs. In many ways, it's not very efficient or stable. So why do we do it?

video:video.video:title: Should there be limits to free speech?
video:video.video:description: Should you be allowed to say what you like, even if it is deeply offensive? Prof Michael Sandel unpicks the issues with a global audience.

video:video.video:title: Why (almost) all world maps are wrong
video:video.video:description: Most modern maps are based on a 450-year-old design, so you'd think they'd be right? They're not - here's why they're actually inaccurate.

video:video.video:title: How to be more creative in daily life
video:video.video:description: From colouring in to the 'vomit draft', actor and writer Kayode Ewumi shares five tips for unleashing your inner creativity.

video:video.video:title: What does it really mean to act your age?

video:video.video:title: The hidden history of the Christmas pudding

video:video.video:title: How do you cope with knowing how you might die?
video:video.video:description: Writer Jean Hannah Edelstein on what it's like to live with an inherited syndrome that increases your chances of cancer.

video:video.video:title: What would life be like without the state?
video:video.video:description: In the first in a new series, Newtopias, artist Gregory Sams sets out his radical vision of a world where the state no longer exists.

video:video.video:title: Keynesianism: The story behind this key economic theory
video:video.video:description: Economist John Maynard Keynes has been hugely influential. But what is Keynesian economic theory? The Economist's Anne McElvoy explains.

video:video.video:title: What would a world without humans be like?
video:video.video:description: What would happen to our world if humans suddenly disappeared? With scientific advice from the OU’s Philip Wheeler.

video:video.video:title: The child who tried to save the world... in 1992
video:video.video:description: In 1992, when she was just 12, Severn Cullis-Suzuki warned the world about the environmental crisis. Here she tells her story.

video:video.video:title: Four things bats can teach us about survival
video:video.video:description: Bats live extraordinarily long lives for their size. From being generous to keeping clean, here's a few tips we could learn from them.

video:video.video:title: An A-Z of living through tough times
video:video.video:description: Spoken word poet Kai-Isiah Jamal shares his experience of growing up in insecure housing.

video:video.video:title: Why smart people do stupid things
video:video.video:description: Some people are smart, but make all sorts of mistakes in their lives. Is that you? Here are four thinking traps clever people fall into.

video:video.video:description: Why are black British women more likely to experience anxiety, depression, panic, and obsessive compulsive disorders than white women?

video:video.video:title: Can we transform the world in 12 years?
video:video.video:description: Scientists say we have 12 years to stop the planet warming above 1.5C. Can we do it? History is full of examples of rapid change.

video:video.video:description: Psychologists report a rise in people suffering from climate change anxiety or eco-anxiety. What’s it like? And what can you do to cope?

video:video.video:title: Will robots take over?
video:video.video:description: Will humanity will be enslaved by intelligent robots?

video:video.video:title: A simple way to get children fit
video:video.video:description: A new project gets kids to run a mile every day - and it's working a treat.

video:video.video:title: We are the DIY generation
video:video.video:description: DJ Jamz Supernova says economic circumstances mean her generation has had to become hustlers.

video:video.video:title: Can trauma be inherited?
video:video.video:description: Theoretical biologist Eva Jablonka explains why she believes the impact of what happens to us could be inherited by future generations.

video:video.video:title: Should we all write in Chinese?
video:video.video:description: What if the whole world used the same writing system?

video:video.video:title: The fabric that changed the way we live
video:video.video:description: From your socks to your singlet - the stretchy fabric that changed fashion forever.

video:video.video:title: 'I became a model in my eighties'
video:video.video:description: Frances Dunscombe became a model in her 80s, and posed nude at 82. She reflects how how she's grown in courage and confidence in later life.

video:video.video:title: My father, Charlie Chaplin

video:video.video:description: Kim Cotton describes what it was like to be the UK's first commercial surrogate.

video:video.video:description: When an astronaut needed help knowing where he was, scientists and scholars were on hand to advise him on a very human problem.

video:video.video:description: When it comes to our main measure for the economy, GDP, even the illegal drugs trade is included.

video:video.video:description: How we came to love eating raw fish - an animated history of sushi, written by food historian Annie Gray.

video:video.video:title: The interactive map that was way ahead of its time
video:video.video:description: Twenty years before the launch of Google Maps, the BBC launched an interactive map distributed by laser disc. Alas it never caught on...

video:video.video:title: Why do we binge-watch (and is it actually good for us)?
video:video.video:description: What makes us binge-watch shows like Killing Eve or Game of Thrones? And is it a problem - or could it actually be good for us?

video:video.video:title: The secret (and science) of how to win at arm-wrestling
video:video.video:description: Want to win at arm-wrestling? These secrets from a pro - the captain of the GB team no less - are guaranteed to give you an edge.

video:video.video:title: Why algorithms are called algorithms
video:video.video:description: Why are algorithms called algorithms? It's thanks to Persian mathematician Muhammad al-Khwarizmi who was born way back in around AD780.

video:video.video:title: Minimalism: Who needs all this stuff anyway!
video:video.video:description: Minimalism is not just about having few possessions - it's also a movement in art and music. David Quantick has a brief history.

video:video.video:title: A potted history of instant noodles
video:video.video:description: How instant noodles went global - with the help of students, workers and prisoners.

video:video.video:title: Generation mute... no talking aloud
video:video.video:description: The people who prefer messaging to talking.

video:video.video:title: Five ways to distraction-proof your mind
video:video.video:description: Why is it so hard to avoid distractions? And how can you get better at it? Here are five tips to help you focus from author Nir Eyal.

video:video.video:title: Hull's 'headscarf revolutionaries'
video:video.video:description: In 1968, a group of women from Hull staged a campaign to improve safety in what was then one of the world's most dangerous industries.

video:video.video:title: How this frog can tell if you're pregnant
video:video.video:description: Before home tests were available, pregnancy tests involved frogs. Yes frogs!

video:video.video:title: Why new habits are so hard to stick to
video:video.video:description: Dr Radha Modgil explains what's going on in our brains when we try to make or break habits.

video:video.video:title: The funny thing about... PTSD
video:video.video:description: Comedian Tom Ward shares this honest insight into life with a type of post-traumatic stress disorder, known as complex PTSD.

video:video.video:title: The Viking club where men fight their demons
video:video.video:description: The Viking clubs which help men who have been scarred by violence.

video:video.video:title: Good cod! A bitesize history of fish and chips
video:video.video:description: Food historian Annie Gray tells the story of that beloved British dish, fish and chips, and how the two came together.

video:video.video:title: The funny thing about... being fat
video:video.video:description: Fat people can find themselves discriminated against. The solution? Not the body positivity movement, argues comedian Sofie Hagen.

video:video.video:title: The godfather of typography
video:video.video:description: Alan Kitching is one of the world’s leading typographers and printmakers. What is the inspiration behind his work?

video:video.video:title: 'Five ways the world is getting better – not worse'
video:video.video:description: In this opinion piece, psychologist and writer Steven Pinker argues that life is improving – not just in the West, but worldwide.

video:video.video:title: Are millennials the most nostalgic generation?
video:video.video:description: It was a time of Game Boys, Tamagotchis and 10p Freddos - but is there more behind millennials love for the 90s? Cai Morgan takes a look.

video:video.video:title: Why we all need a bit of childlike wonder
video:video.video:description: Imagine a world where scientists were the people kids dreamed of becoming. Astrophysicist Karen Masters does just that.

video:video.video:title: Breaking taboos with tattoos
video:video.video:description: Tattoos can be frowned upon in Asian culture, but tattoo artist Heleena Mistry is trying to challenge this.

video:video.video:title: A very (very) brief history of newsflashes
video:video.video:description: "We interrupt this broadcast..." From the end of WW2 to interrupting Mrs Brown's Boys - how newsflashes changed through the decades.

video:video.video:title: When globalisation makes you feel like you don't belong
video:video.video:description: Author Aatish Taseer reflects on the changes that migration and urbanisation have brought to people's lives.

video:video.video:title: A love letter to Ceefax
video:video.video:description: Who doesn't like a bit of nostalgia? We remember Ceefax, the teletext service that gave us news and a whole lot more at our fingertips.

video:video.video:title: The quiet power of introverts
video:video.video:description: Are you an introvert? If so, that's great! Sofja Umarik (who is an introvert) looks at how it can be a real strength.

video:video.video:title: Is 'black don't crack' a myth?
video:video.video:description: Poet Theophina Gabriel dispels the myth that black skin does not age - it's more complicated than that.

video:video.video:title: How music can free your mind
video:video.video:description: Writer Adam Gopnik explains why rock music played such a key role in bringing about change in autocratic states.

video:video.video:title: The funny thing about... feminism
video:video.video:description: For anyone who doubts the need for feminism, here's a thought experiment from comedian Deborah Frances-White.

video:video.video:title: Why some songs make you feel really old
video:video.video:description: Writer Rhodri Marsden explores how music has a unique effect on our concept of time.

video:video.video:title: Xenophobism: The story of its ancient roots

video:video.video:title: Do we have a right not to be lonely?

video:video.video:title: How to do less... but get more done

video:video.video:title: What does freedom mean to a child?

video:video.video:title: Why is the common cold so hard to cure?

video:video.video:description: !Jante Law is a set of rules that underpin Scandinavian society. It seems to help create equality - but at what expense to the individual?

video:video.video:title: Ruby Wax’s guide to mindfulness
video:video.video:description: The comedian shares her tips on helping your mind become a calmer, more contented place.

video:video.video:description: Strangers are sharing unwanted food in a bid to save money and reduce food waste.

video:video.video:title: How to win at poohsticks

video:video.video:title: Is social media messing with our emotions?
video:video.video:description: Author Laurence Scott believes social media is changing the way that we express emotions.

video:video.video:title: The simple recipe for a happy street

video:video.video:title: Does birth order really matter?
video:video.video:description: There are lots of stereotypes about the eldest child, youngest child and middle child... But are there really birth order characteristics?

video:video.video:description: What makes some of us want to travel far and wide - while others are happier staying at home? Is there such a thing as a "wanderlust gene"?

video:video.video:title: What Wimbledon has done for fashion
video:video.video:description: From Centre Court to catwalk - how Wimbledon has shaped fashion through the years.

video:video.video:title: How curry conquered Britain

video:video.video:title: The gesture that speaks a thousand words
video:video.video:description: The story of the clenched fist hand gesture - from symbol of resistance to fist pump emoji.

video:video.video:title: How to win at rock-paper-scissors

video:video.video:description: Love a good G&T? Food historian Annie Gray on the history of gin and tonic - and how they came together.

video:video.video:title: Four things whales can teach us about life
video:video.video:description: From knowing your roots to singing your song, us humans can learn a thing or two from whale culture.

video:video.video:description: Richard Simcott is a hyperpolyglot, meaning he has a gift for learning new languages.

video:video.video:description: Knife crime and youth violence are rarely out of the news - musician and mentor Femi Koleoso says we can all play a role in tackling them.

video:video.video:description: How an 'improv' comedy class in Toronto has helped people with anxiety.

video:video.video:description: Meet Mabel, the robot housemaid.

video:video.video:description: Author Kamila Shamsie reflects on Antigone - an ancient Greek play she believes has parallels with modern Britain.

video:video.video:title: What to do if your boss is an algorithm
